The Lord of the castle of is old, and grey headed;
fourscore years have pass flitted over him silently and unaware, and the dream of
life is nigh to its awaking, and his ear is dull, and his
eye is dim, and his heart is weary.
The old man reclines on a couch in the hall of his
ancestors, and beside an open casement, and the balmy
air that dri floats over the deep blue waters of the broad
sea passes softly over his gleaming hair; and his weary
eye rests on the brightness of an exceeding lovely landscape ;
for the olive and the orange and the myrtle are green
by the shore of the still waters, and the city gleams whitely
beneath the glance of the sun as he rides through the
cloudless azure of the to heaven, and the purple mountains
clasp the ocean in their arms, and fade away into the horizon,
in long lines of misty blue.

Alas, the spring time of nature is a mockery to the
winter of oldage , and the old man turns away in sadness .
He is begins by His vassals are waiting around him to
do him pleasure, the minstrel is there with his harp, the maiden with her song, but no music is so sweet to
the old mans ear as the voice of his daughter Giulietta.
Giulietta, when a babe, was a thing of smiles and loveliness
like a happy thought dancing over the mind
Giulietta, when a child, was like the orange blossom in
the groves of Friuli, and gladness floated around her like the
fragrance of the flower . Giulietta in her youth is the
fairest maiden of Italy, — she glanced among the myrtle
bowers like the wayward winged zephyr, the evening star when
it trembles and rises gleaming out of the sea into
the darkness of the glorious night of Italy , is not so
bright as the big beam that flashed from her large eye
through the night of her lovely eye lashes.
Like music to the sadness of the soul, so was Giulietta
to the old age of her father, as she passed before him
a light came into the coldness of his eye, and his ear,
when it was dead to other sound, awoke to the murmur
of her gentle voice. (Giuliettaʼs mind was love, all love
continual love to each and every thing, the birds
knew Giulietta, (the nightingale sang at her chamber window,
his song to the stars,) and (as she walked among the
flowers they fluttered beside her and stooped their glossy necks
to her hand) nay, the flowers seemed to know Giulietta
and to be gladdened into brightness as she pass, and Giulietta
loved them all.) To her father, –as an angel watches
over the last days of a saint upon the earth , when the tumult
of the battle of his life is oer, and sheds peace around his hours
and bids his days pass sweetly and holily, so Giulietta watched
over the old man like an influence of good and was the sun of his
thoughts, and the light of his rejoicing .
Giulietta had a brother . Garcio was feared by many
and loved by few, was a man of a dark countenance
and the shadows of his evil passions past over it like clouds
over the luridness of the stormy heaven; and his look withered
those upon whom it fell, and his wrath once excited raged
like a pestilence, and would not be appeased; he was feared by
all, hated by many, loved by few, but his arm was resistless in the
battle, and his fame was higher among the proud names
of the warriors of Italy.
Among his many enemies, Garcio hated none as he did
the bandit Leoni, for him only he feared.
There are spirits warring on the earth, which are not of
a like order with their fellows, which will rise above the
ordinary dust of mortality, whether it be in greatness of evil,
or of good, and it depends upon the accident of impulse,
upon the treatment of their fellow men, whether their greatness
is be a blessing or a curse, and such was Leoni (he was
what he abhorred,) for (his noble nature had been borne down
by the violence of his passions), but yet his name was pronounced
with fear, but not with scorn or contumely, and widely
was the fear of that name spread, for he passed over
the land like a meteor and left desolation behind him
in the halls of the great and the powerful, but not in
the hamlets of the poor.
Returning from a successful attack on the castle of a
neighbouring baron, Leoni had been once tracked to the
fastnesses of the Apennines by Garcio, with a chosen
troop of his followers. The bandit gave him battle, and
was as usual victorious. The followers of Garcio cowered
back from the charge of the bandit his thunderbolt charge and Garcio himself was
struck from his horse by the sword of their leader. Leoni
It had been said of Leoni that he had never spared deserted
a friend, or spared an enemy, but suddenly as his sword waved
over the head of his prostrate foe, the beaver of Garcioʼs helmet fell open his arm was checked as if
by the hand of an invisible being, * and to the astonishment
of his followers, Leoni sounded a retreat in the very flush of victory
and the Garcio and his band so disheartened and vanquished
band were suffered to retire unmolested.
* a smile of scorn passed over his lip, and then a mildness came
into the flash of his eye, a mildness rarely never before seen on the features of
Leoni; he turned calmly away, and to the astonishment
From that time the hatred of Garcio to Leoni was as
a consuming fire, and the shame of defeat, and the
thirst of revenge gnawed into his heart like vultures—
he had rather have been laid dead by the sword of Leoni
than suffered to be a monument of the clemency of this
bandit conqueror.
Giulietta, Giulietta, said the old man.

like the moon when it is bright among the pale stars
and she knelt down silently softly besides her parent, and lifted

Giulietta, said the old man, there is a dark spirit upon
me to day, a shadow that is felt, a dread stillness of the wind
like the fearful hush of the air before the desolation of
the earthquake, a chill is upon my soul as if the hand
of death were lying cold even upon my mind
Nay, my father, said Giulietta, thou art weary, and she bent over him and kissed his cheek.
I am not weary when thou art beside me Giulietta,
this gloom that sits brooding over my heart is not weakness
or disease, it is a presentiment of evil which the invisible beings
who are round us in the air and in us, and who watch over our feelings
and turn them to good or to evil, have power to infuse into
our souls as a warning—Such there are. Giulietta, I have
spoken with them in my mind. I have felt their power ruling
over my life. I have felt them busy about my heartstrings
in Joy or in sorrow—
My father, said Giulietta, the evil spirits have no power
over us without our own consent, and this midnight of
the soul is not of the good.
I know not, returned the old man, I have felt it once before
it was followed by the death of those whom I loved.
